ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This class reads early 18th century novels alongside contemporary ones and tracks the evolution of the novel form, with a focus on themes of fictionality, commodification, and intersectionality as they operate in the 18th century and today. In addition to reading a lot of great books, this course helped me to develop the skills of close reading and literary comparison/analysis, as well as both academic and creative writing.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think that at times for certain novels a trigger warning should have been given. However, overall I think the books we read this semester flowed well into one another with content as well as overarching themes.
Prof. Campbell is a huge strength. I also enjoyed the readings, though difficulty varied between 18th and 21st century texts. Lots of reading but assignments were very reasonable.
I really enjoyed this course, and I thought that it was very well-constructed to facilitate student learning.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, Prof. Campbell leads great discussions each class and gives very thorough feedback on papers. She is all-around a wonderful and kind professor who will teach you so much just from speaking with her. Papers are very flexible.

I would recommend this course to any student interested in English, writing, politics, or history. It was fascinating to learn about the origins of the novel form and to track the differences (and surprising similarities) between centuries and writers. In addition to being incredibly understanding and kind, Professor Campbell is an insightful speaker and discussion-leader, and I really enjoyed the class's simultaneous exploration of novelistic techniques and socio-political trends.
